description:
If you're looking for a perfect blend of savory and spice; the spicy beef noodle soup is the way to go. Ordered the spicy beef noodle soup after a long day of studying. It was perfect with enough meat and noodles. I had some left over for the following day and it tasted just as delicious as the first night!

Customer service was great. Our waitress was very kind and took our orders right away. We did not wait long for the food to come out. I will definitely come back!
author: rosanna b.

description:
OMG! This is the best Szechuan restaurant for hot pot I have tried myself! I very like  hot pots and I'm willing to try all types of the hot pots. Chinese, Korean, Japanese, etc. 

Referred by a friend, went to Spicy Queen Szechuan Cuisine to try the hot pot. This is the far better hot pot than any hot pot restaurants I have tried before. We have the half and half soup base with the original and spicy. The original soup was so fresh and tasty, and the spicy soup was even better, the soup was hot and delicious. It added the spicy favorites to the meats and vegetables. The spicy dipping sauces come with the orders are very good too. 

The services are excellent and the waitresses always come to our table to make sure we have everything we want. 

Parking was no problem when we are here on Tuesday evening at about 6:30pm. We have a street parking in front of the restaurant. 

I know I'll come back again and again every time when I come to San Francisco. This is a must try hot pot restaurant if you love hot and spicy hot pot!
author: Michael W.

description: Hello friends this is your Chinese food yelper. I would say this place is a very legitimate Szechuan flavored Chinese restaurant. Came here for the noodles and chicken and I would say both tasted very authentic and had the right amount of Mala. For those who don't know what m a l a means it is a type of spiciness where your mouth and tongue feels slightly numb tingling from the Szechuan peppercorn. I took one star off just because the restaurant felt too cramped for me and also the AC could have been turned up.
author: Ben C.

description:
I'm a fan! 

All this cold weather calls for some hot pot! 

Came here with my friend and let him do all the ordering since this was my first time and this was one of his favorite places.

He ordered the double pot of soup one non spicy that had goji berries and dried dates which are super foods and ingredients for a healthy soup and the other soup which appeared to be oil and chilis. Don't let this intimidate you, it was very flavorful. It's not ayce so you pick the plates of the items you want and dipping sauce is extra. 

He ordered the fish, fish balls with roe, enoki, Napa cabbage, quail eggs, tofu, greens and marinated beef for me. I'd skip the marinated beef because I'm used to thinly sliced beef and the beef was small thick cuts of beef probably better in a stir fry dish. I was actually really surprised by the amount of meat though for the price it was. I'd consider trying one of their other meats or not because I was happy with everything else. Fish ball roe is a must if you've never tried it. The roe in the middle will knock your socks off.

The spicy side of the pot caught me a bit off guard but turned out to be not that spicy. Being this is food from Sichuan I was expecting it to be numbing and tingling but thankfully it wasn't any of that. The flavor tasted of a citrus, peppercorn, star anise flavoring and I love how the flavor infuses into the fish, tofu, and quail eggs. I didn't order sauce but the food seemed flavorful that it didn't need sauce. 

The other side of the pot was a little on the plainer side and I can't describe what the flavor was will have to ask for more details the next time I visit but the more items we dumped into it the more flavorful it got. Best part was they refilled our soup pot towards the end and my friend suggested I take the non spicy soup home and make porridge with it. *mind blown* did exactly that. It did not disappoint. Can't wait to come back especially since this is my friends favorite pl
author: Lindsay C.

description:
Long Live the Spicy Queen!!!

So glad I wandered into this place. The outside of the restaurant seemed authentic...decorated in chinese characters and photos of the flaming hot szechuan dishes. The decor inside Spicy Queen is reminiscent of a local village hot pot shop. It has a fancy dining pagoda that seats 5, and several booths and tables equipped with the hot pot heating mechanism built into the table. 

The food is CHEAP! Lunch specials are served M-F from 11am-4pm. It includes a variety of meat/veggie combos with rice for only $9!!! Or if you are ordering off the regular menu, those options are reasonably priced as well. There is the hot pot option: purchase the hot pot base soup, and order additional items to cook for your meal. I will say the dishes are a little on the oily side, but that doesn't bother me with szechuan style food. 

I highly recommend the following: 
-Tan Tan Noodles
-Onion Pancake
-Ma po tofu

A nice addition to your stay in the hot pot kingdom is free green tea! It's served in the HEAVIEST teapots allowed in this galaxy. The density alone could introduce a new black hole. 

Service is not great. That's the ONLY reason Spicy Queen is not receiving 5 stars. The servers are not the most attentive to timing with orders and bringing the free tea out. Always be sure to ask! But once you do, no problems :) 

Bottom Line: Cheap pagoda eatin' szechuan cuisine.
author: Jaime W.

description:
My favorite Chinese restaurant in SF! They serve authentic Chinese food from the Sichuan region. 

Hotpot: you have to try their segmented hotpot because it just look so damn cool. It has holes between the segments so the broth is actually one pot, except for you can locate your food better. It is filled with pepper which looks scary but it's not too spicy that you lose your ability to taste. My husband who usually order mild in restaurants thinks that it has a good kick but is still very edible. The choices for hotpot is below average because they serve a lot of other food than hotpot. I like to order lamb, beef, fish fillets, lotus root, mushroom, and tofu. 
 
Other dishes: Dry sautéed string beans, Couples delight, scallion pancake, wuhan hot dry noodle, moo tofu, and House special land ribs is TO DIE FOR! It is authentic xinjiang lamb, which is very rare in the US.

Tips:
1. Their menu has photos next to nearly every dish, which is very helpful for non-Chinese diners. 
2. Their original location, Spicy King, is located in China town. It serves the same food but is usually busier.
author: Tata X.

description:
Good spot for spicy Szechuan food.. lots of variety on the menu and they have hotpot as well.

Appetizers:
- Lamb Skewers (5/5): love the cumin & spices, very tender.. my favorite of the items we tried. Definitely on the reorder list!

- Sliced Pork Belly in Spicy garlic sauce (4/5): cold appetizer that isn't spicy. Overall it was good, the thin slices of cucumbers made the dish a tiny bit healthier, I guess. Not sure if necessarily need to reorder this dish since there are so many other items on the menu to try out.

Entree:
Silly Tofu & Chicken in Numbing Sauce (3/5): I was a bit worried that I'd lose all my tastebuds and wouldn't be able to taste all the flavors but that wasn't the case. It definitely had a kick to it but at least for me it wasn't all that spicy... my tolerance for spicy food has gone up though. If you're sensitive to spicy food.. opt for another dish since "numbing" is the highest level of spiciness. As for the dish itself.. I definitely wouldn't order it again. We were forewarned that the chicken had bones but this was literally more bones than meat.. it seems like it's small pieces near the cavity of the chicken. The dish was also way too salty.. I must've drank two whole pots of piping hot tea at the restaurant and downed another gallon of water when I went back home (ok maybe a bit of an exaggeration but you get the point!).
author: Ruby C.

description:
Great tasting Szechuan food that was prepared well with excellent flavors and a decent amount of heat with the spicy dishes.  

Only dish I had a minor issue is with the House Special Lamb Shank.  Wonderfully seasoned, but it wasn't enough to mask off the gaminess of the lamb.

The other two dishes we ordered were seasoned well and delicious: Wontons in Spicy Chile Broth and the 3-Flavored Vegetable Sautéed.

Service was OK.
author: Sklar T.

description:
The food here was above average compared to other szechuan places. The wontons were average and the 3 mixed vegetables were above average. The house special lamb was not bad but rather meh for szechuan style food. There was no detectable spiciness, they used fermented black beans for the flavoring. Must be a very homey dish.

3 dishes was not a wide enough spectrum to make a fair judgement on the restaurant but it certainly was not a disaster or something to avoid altogether.
author: Keo N.

description:
Super courteous service 5 * 
My favorite dish is the couple's delight , the spicy sizzling hot fish in sizzling plate , stir fried potato strip  would come back again !!!!
author: Phoebe W.

description:
Pretty legit Sichuan food

Saw the yelp reviews and decided to stop by. The photos looked awesome. In real life, the place did not disappoint!

The decor inside is real. Everything from the stone cutlery, the "stone" tea kettle that is heavy but looked like what you'd get from ancient ties, to the wall decorations to the attire of the wait staff are all pretty close to what you'd felt if you were in Sichuan. Nice!

The food is nice, especially the spicy chong qing noodles. Lots of spice--the moment you bite into it you can smell the roasted spice and the chilly oil. The spiciness is a little low, so be sure to ask for extra spicy. The same goes for the spicy beef--the taste, the oil is all so good. Just need more spiciness. The cumin lamb meat skewers were a little dry, and stuck onto the wooden sticks, which made it really hard to get the meat off. But still, the meat tasted really good!

Worth coming back, especially for spicy food!
author: Henry L.

description: The fish is selicious and has good look. But with little meat. Too expensive. I went with my friend. We spend 53 each person
author: Ying C.

description:
Most of the dishes were flavorful. Some were spicy, but well balanced, so that the distinctive flavors and tastes were not overwhelmed by the hotness of the peppers and chilis.

Hits included the Cumin Pork Neck, Chongqing Noodles, Fish in Flaming Chili Oil, Spicy Beef Tendon, and Lamb with Peppers.

The Sesame Chicken was extremely sweet and seemed out of place.

Service was limited to order taking and bringing out the food. Otherwise we were on our own.
author: David W.

description: It is good at atmosphere and the ambience. But the spicy taste might not be the exact Sichuan or Chongqing style.
author: Lin Z.

description:
We had lunch this Wednesday at Spicy Queen went we met friends who worked a couple blocks away. Its located on Geary Blvd with parking at a premium. The decor looks like a converted Japanese restaurant with a bar on the back wall. If you don't like or can't handle spicy food this is not the restaurant for you. 80% of menu is spicy hot food. The food was you typical Szechaun Chung Ching faire. The fancy trifold menu is a bit confusing with the noodles being the highlight. 

Spicy Boiled Fish was just ok looked better then it was.
Fu Qi Feh Pian. Was good with different slices of beef tendon tripe and beef
Veggie tofu soup was terrible a pork broth with some bock coy and tofu thrown in
Spicy Chung Ching Noodles with peas the best dish excellent flavor 
Sour bean with Minced Pork was good
Green onion pancake was " deep fried " very greasy
Lamb skewers were ok only 4 tiny skewers see pics
Drunken Chicken was good
Smoked pork belly with green beans was flavorful but super salty
Take out deep fried pork shank was good.

Service was OK. They charge for take out containers even for to go orders. Parking is hard during the day. $120 before tip
author: George F.

description: We came in looking for hot pot as there used to be a few different hot pot restaurants here.  Everything is individual and not all you can eat.  Prefer all you can eat so I can have unlimited veggies, sauces etc..  menu is scattered as to many items, bathrooms clean, waitress never brought water until we asked again for it.
author: Ruth M.

description:
I was really excited to try this place after reading many good reviews about the food's authenticity and I just found out the owners also own the Chongqing Xiao Mian restaurant on Kearney in Chinatown (which I really like) and are ex-Z&Y (one of my favorites).

My wife and I ordered 3 dishes for lunch earlier today:

Kung Pao Chicken
Mapo Tofu
Red Oil Wontons

The red oil wontons came in a huge noodle bowl with a lot of broth, but the flavor was just ok.  Filling for the wontons tasted like pork and possibly some shrimp, but skin was pretty thick and tasted surprisingly bland

The mapo tofu I had really high hopes for especially when they put it down on our table.  There was a ton of sichuan peppercorn on top, but that flavor didn't come through either (maybe ground too long ago?) AND the sauce was more brown than red (I would have preferred much more hot bean paste and/or chili oil vs soy sauce) and the tofu was just a little firm for me.

The Kung pao chicken dish was good, but a little sweet. 

I still put Z&Y/Chili House and Sichuan Home above Spicy Queen in terms of flavor.
author: Howard T.

description:
Been here a few times now and really enjoy it. If you like spicy hot you'll love this place. But don't let that scare you away if your not into spicy hot. They have non spicy options too. 

They've got large table and can handle a good sized group of people. 

They serve beer and wine. The staff is nice and I enjoy their food.
author: Kyle G.

description:
worst eating place ever
The food is disgusting and the waitress is rude.
The noodle is way too salty and the Hotpot is tasteless.
Not to mention the other dishes. 
Everything here is terrible and they will force you to add more tips even though they don't deserve it.
author: 昕

description:
A great place for Szechuan style Chinese food. Szechuan = spicy so rightly named as spicy queen. had lunch special here for $9 bucks. for 9 dollars there is plenty of food. the lunch special comes with a hot & sour soup or Egg drop soup based on what they have for the day. it comes with hot tea in a tea pot. it comes with one entrée and steamed rice. the ambience is great. the place is well maintained. service is quick. metered parking outside the restaurant. they best part is the menu is user friendly with pictures of the food so you can get a visual aid to your decision.

I ordered Kung pao chicken lunch special. the Kung pao chicken was spicy. the quantity was good. the sauce was right. the steamed rice was cooked enough, it wasn't too much boiled or less. 

why 4 stars vs 5. the amount of meat in the kung pao chicken was less and was of more vegetables. can add a few more pieces to make it perfect. 

Bottom line will visit this place again.
author: Suresh D.

description:
Very much a Chinese experience at its worst. I have had high hopes, and a lot of great deal of Sichuan restaurants experiences, both in China and in the states. We walked by this place since it first opened, like million or so times. Really hope that it'll be good. 

Food is oily. I have never had a Sichuan hot oil boiled beef dish with this heavy gravy sauce before. It's super salty, barely edible. I don't know what it is called. I can't imagine any Chinese chain restaurant could survive this kind of non authentic dishes, but maybe they made it for the Americans here, but still the restaurant is filled with mainlander Chinese, you think you'd get at least an authentic dish but no such luck. The ribs were deep fried, flavorful but seemed to be coated with MSG. The Dan Dan noodles should be easy to make, heck I make it at home, but it did not appear to even look like the picture printed on the menu. 

Table is greasy. The door is not shut and cannot be shut fully, and there was no heat, so we ate with our coats on, terribly cold winter night. The most horrific experience is the bathroom, where there were literately piss everywhere on the seat, a little dose of China right there and then. To give you slightly more of a taste what a lousy but typical chinese restaurant in China would do, they also announce that they charge a container fee, not much like 25 cents or something, but really? Can't you just built the price in? 

I have eaten in many different Sichuan places. My step mother was from Chongqing. I know what a mediocre place looks like: both in China and in the states. I also know when it's been Americanized and / or just a Taiwanese Sichuan joint. 

We were debating between this one or Terra Cotta Warrior on the other side of the park. It was really a toss but I think we'd enjoyed it more there, at least it looked cleaner. 

Here is the silver lining of eating at a Chinese chain restaurant's very first outpost in America: you really can get just about anything in the Avenues. even a lousy Chinese restaurant that would be considered lousy in China. Enthusiasm is curbed.  We really should have stuck with our original plan of eating at Stein's.
author: Victoria E.

description:
Ordered takeout from this place and I cannot help the 5 star rating bc their food is tops.  Maybe I revisit the review once I dine in for a more well rounded review but for now... Just the food. 

Ordered mapo tofu, cucumber salad, and chongqiing hot numbing spicy noodle.  The mapo tofu was well seasoned, good sized tofu, and well cooked.  The cucumber salad was a good combination of garlic, salt, and vinegar.  The chongqiing noodles were highly addictive due to the immense flavor and the way every bite leaves your mouth tingling.  They used just the right amount of chili oil to add the heat but without masking the awesome flavor.  

I'm already planning my next food order from this place... Long live the Queen! Spicy Queen!
author: Dan O.

description:
[No More in This Restaurant!!!!!!] 
The dish tasted not fresh. My friend found people's hair on the fish. The waitress said we could return it or exchange. We said return. But when we were checking out, the waitress said we could not return, we have to pay for the fish. (WHAT??!!)  it was so ridiculous!!!!
Never come again ! No more! The service was also bad. We were sitting there about 15mins, and ask the waitress for tea, then she brought us tea.....
(Zero star for this restaurant)
author: Jie W.

description: I like it...a lot.  Must say I'm concerned that so many Asians gave it low marks.  I always figure they are more aware.  Me, I like to see what can be done with kidney or intestine or feet, and I have a very high tolerance for spice levels.  This place knows what to do.  I had them go for 10/10 on the heat, and it was intense but not overwhelming spicy.  Had the pig feet and a tofu dish, delicious.  Didn't try the hotpot, probably won't as this isn't my go to thing.  I'll try it again, look for something not to like and update if needed.  I did lunch, btw, and service was fine.
author: Bob S.

description: It might have been an off night, but there was crazy stomping going on from a party upstairs. Kind of disconcerning since they didn't really try to stop it. Had the dry fried green beans, sweet and sour pork, and a dish that had intestines, fish, bean curd, all floating in hot chillies. The last dish was definitely spicy and flavorful, but I'm not a fan of intestines no matter how well cleaned they are. Green beans were acceptable, but I wouldn't order the spare ribs again.
author: Gaelyn O.

description:
This place stands out like a sore thumb at night on Geary St.  The multi-colored neon lights look like something you'd see along a street food alley way in China.

This place looks so tacky from the outside, I knew there had to be great Chinese food inside.

And there was...

Let's start with the menu, there's a lot going on there, but realistically, even that's only half of the food choices served here.  They have another paper sheet for hotpot where you can order hotpot food (food you cook yourself) rather than the made-to-order dishes from the actual menu.  My party came more for the hotpot so that's what we got!

Hot Pot (Half herbal / Half Spicy):
The herbal soup is great, once the herbal soup comes to a boil, try a small bowl for taste.  The spicy side... could be a bit more spicier and more numbing, I mean for a place that is called Spicy Queen, I expected "Spicy Queen".  The meats here are all pretty darn good, the surprising one being the beef tripe, I'm not usually a fan of tripe, but this stuff is good!  I would not be afraid to order anything else on the menu after trying this.

Dipping Sauce:
Yes, order the dipping sauces!!! They come in a large bowl each so it's shareable by the table and they are amazing!  The soup bases are already pretty flavorful, but the sauce really seals the deal!

Grilled Squid - pretty damn good and well made, eat this quick while it's still hot!  Don't let it cool down while you're scarfing down on your hotpot foods, those can wait!

The inside of the place can get quite stuffing, hot pot, chili spices, crowded space with bad ventilation can make this place feel like a steam room, so it does get quite warm while you're dining here, grabbing a cold dessert nearby isn't a bad idea afterwards.

Overall, this place is a 3.5 stars in some areas but the certain unique dishes (like their tripe) and the fact that this place looks so tacky yet still tastes good makes this a solid 4 in my book.
author: Mike L.

description: The foods are authentic. I just can't understand why the English names of the restaurant and the menu are small. It seems like only Chinese dine in the restaurant. I like it very much, and I hope there will be one in LA
author: 翔

description: Food is not bad.  price are a little high . People seem pretty nice. It's pretty dark in there. What's the most crazy is they charge 50 cents for boxes of leftover takeout. That's crazy.
author: Food Is L.

description: Been there several times though disappointed every time.....some food is too salty while others are not spicy enough.
author: Danyang W.

description:
Came here for hotpot, which was just OK.
- We got the dual broths, both if which were pretty flavorful.  But the spicy one wasn't very hot for a place whose name is Spicy Queen.
- The meat was low quality.  The beef was frozen and not well marbled.  The lamb was frozen and oddly cut.  The pork belly was cut into strange shreds and were probably 90% fat.  I love fatty pork belly, but this was even too fatty for me, as there were no contrasting layers of lean meat and fat.
- You have to pay for the sauces, which just feels wrong.

It's not all you can eat, but i left very full, and $64 for two people is comparable to an AYCE place.  Seemed like the rest of the massive menu might hold some promise, but I probably wouldn't come back for hot pot.
author: Simon L.

description: Horrible and disgusting!! The worst restaurant I have gone so far in San Francisco! Extremely terrible service I have met!!  The waitress offered an impolite, rude,and impatient attitude to guests!! We waited a long long time; however, they told us "We have right to refuse service to you!!!".....All right, it is the first time to hear and meet in a restaurant on the earth!! Soooooooo bad and my friends told me they had same and similar bad experience in this restaurant too!! What the hell????!!!!! In addition, the food is not fresh and nothing can be worse than it!!
author: Sonya S.

description:
Came here for hot pot. It's not all you can eat.

Ordered double broth $8.95: half spicy and half chicken herb. The spicy was mild version and it still gave quite a kick. The half chicken herb is well flavored

If you order what you usually do for hot pot, the only thing that stood out from other hot pot places were:

Tofu bean curd: very thinly sliced and cooks In a few seconds. 

Pork: not your ordinary sliced pork but marinated and was very juicy after cooking

Beef: not a fan since meat came out frozen and was not as fresh after cooking

Potstickers: larger than the usual places and seems actually fresh made instead of frozen form. 

The rest we ordered were not out of the ordinary and did not stand out from the rest of the other hot pot places: Napa cabbage, fish tofu, spinach, potstickers, enoki mushroom and shittake mushroom. 

What makes this place only worth coming back is the both the spicy and chicken herb broths.
author: Joanne K.

description: After spending 84 dollars for two people on a hot pot dinner, we walked out still hungry. Their hot pot could easily be the worst I have ever had and I have had a lot of hot pot. The meat was so thick and frozen and much worse than the frozen hot pot meat you pick up from Chinese super market. The dipping sauce was ridiculous. We asked for sesame sauce (most of the hot pot places have a dipping sauce station where you can make your own sauce) and this place just serves straight up sesame sauce with nothing in it. If you were Chinese, you know the sesame sauce comes with Chinese leek paste and marinated tofu. I asked the waitress and the best she could do was to give me soy sauce. The hot pot soup base along was 8 dollars and it barely had any favor. I was so disappointed by their hot pot. Huge mistake for having hot pot here.
author: K Y.

description:
Horrible. 
Husband and I ordered food here (hot pots of some kind), and we literally got two bowls of watery broth with some cabbage = $60 dollars. There was maybe 1 carrot slice floating around in there along with a piece of hair. We didn't even order side items. 

We left, stunned.
author: Mima G.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday night for a table of five and it wasn't too busy so we got to sit right away. There seems to be only one guy bussing all the tables which made service slightly slower and less attentive. 

The chopsticks are a little old since the wooden fibers started flaring out - not appetizing. We started with the cucumber salad which was super tasty and refreshing. Since I'm not a lamb fan, my friends ordered the lamb skewers and didn't think it was too bad. We then got our main courses of tan tan noodles, spicy beef noodle soup, and guiling noodle soup. The noodles were very long so it took us awhile to scoop out but that's better than short noodles. They're very spicy even though I requested for mild since I can't handle too spicy. My boyfriend had the guiling noodle soup and it was very flavorful, but compared to the spicy noodles, it was much less interesting. I they also serve a yogurt drink to help cool down the spicy, which is also good for the digestive. Not bad for spicy food lovers, but not too bad for me since I could request for less spicy.

For five people, our bill came out to be about $20 each person including tips - not bad!
author: Amanda C.

description: The price goes proportional to the portion. The food were very tasty. One of my favorite restaurants in SF.
author: Csrocker C.

description:
small pot rice noodle was good
beef noodle soup was ok
beef stripe was good
author: Diane W.

description: I am highly satisfied with the Hot Pot. It is quite authentic Chengdu / Chongqing Hot Pot. It is my first time trying the Jiugongge Hot Pot in the US. Besides, the dishes and the noodle are also delicious. You get lots of choices here. However, I think the ingredients they use is just OKAY.
author: Shikai L.

description: Amazing Chinese food, better than probably 99 percent of other Szechuan restaurant in the state， if you are looking for something like walnut shrimp plz go the panda, right here they serve most authentic Szechuan outside of China . ordered pork dishes it was delicious. Will be back when I visit SF Again
author: Xiaoyu Z.

description:
I dont understander why every one say its good，is so bad， is not sichuan style and very expensive !!!⋯
i ordered BBQ and noodle......only 2 item ⋯and payed $21！！i never back again⋯⋯never⋯⋯
author: Lily W.

description: Not a bad place. Everything is like spicy! Lol I guess that's the name. Didn't try the hot pot but got a lot of the noodle dishes. Me and my friends got the tan tan noodles, chongqing noodles, beef noodle soup, and the eggplant dish. It's all very good and the spicy flavor is there. It's not a bad place and people should try it out. I can't say it's super amazing but the food is good for not really waiting. Next time I want to try the hot pot and see how that goes. Place is clean which always a good thing in my book.
author: Jackie N.

description:
Really great place for spicy szechuan hot pot. We ordered the double broth hot pot ($8.95) , which gives you the spicy szechuan broth, but also the non-spicy herbal broth. It's great for those who love spicy, but also need something not as spicy to balance out. The meats, fish filet, mushrooms are all $5.95 and the vegetables/tofu are $3.95. There are plenty of options - my favourite is the fish filet because it's really good when cooked in the spicy broth - the fish remains tender.

The service always seems to be a bit slow here. I don't think they have many servers and the place gets really packed. Good idea to make a reservation prior to coming as to avoid long waits. But I definitely recommend if you have a lot of time to chill/eat with friends.
author: Shihyung H.

description:
A friend organized a NBA Finals game three party in their 2nd floor private room which has an 80" TV.  Walking through the main dining room, I was directed to a set of stairs midway down to the left leading there.  It's definitely roomy and comfortable as there were sofas positioned around the big screen.
Arriving a bit late, half of our party of fourteen were enjoying (not really, since the Warriors trailed early on) the game while the other half were having conversations at the large circular table for fourteen.  To secure this room, our organizer negotiated a set dollar minimum ($500.00) for our party.  They ordered appetizers and small bites to start and it was BYOB which is a nice perk for those wanting their choice of imbibe.  We munched on a variety of small marinated dishes like preserved egg, tofu, seaweed, pig ears, and chicken (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q); the green onion pancakes weren't bad either.  As everyone's appetites grew, everyone returned to the main table as the waitress set up two burners, one already imbedded in the table and another electric tabletop one (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).  The main burner had two broths, an herbal one with goji berries and a spicy one that looked intimidating but wasn't that bad; the tabletop one had a special spicy lamb broth which I didn't try since it was a bit of a reach from my seat.
Then, came the proteins which included mussels, shrimp on a stick (easier to cook), thinly sliced beef and lamb, and an assortment of veggies and tofu skin, tofu, quail eggs, enoki mushrooms, and fish and meat balls.  Trying to pace myself, I took my time which proved to be at my disadvantage.  Around 8:30 pm, the power on both the in-table burner and the plug in burner both shut off... as in there was no electricity.  Interesting since the large screen TV, the wall mounted smaller TV, and the lights were all still operational.  After about thirty minutes of searching and checking the wire, fuses, and other causes for this disruption, our waitress found an old school gas (butane can) burner, but only one for fourteen people.  As the game winded down after a gallant Golden State comeback, the Cavs prevailed and most everyone was hungover from the loss.  Also, since the restaurant closes at 10 pm and it was around 9:30 pm before the burner was back on, we decided to order a variety of drinks, appetizers, and green onion pancakes to bring our total closer to the minimum; we ended up around $330.00 before gratuity and, given the technical difficulties, the owner was kind to waive the minimum for our particular situation.  Nothing really stood out and the situation was awkward and unusual since we didn't get a full taste of the potential of this place.  
Will try to come back and give it another try, but the experience left more of a bitter taste than a numbing one.
author: Mike C.

description:
holy moly. this is the chinese food of my youth! i love the decor, portion sizes, homey vibe.
The best hot and sour soup evah. Not to mention the mixed veggies - they were even better the next day.

The prices are affordable for individual dishes & there's more than enough leftovers.

Highly recommend!
author: Twinstar G.

description: Went there three times! Like hotspot a lot~ nice service not very big place and good taste!
author: Momoko S.

description: I come from Szechuan, and I have to say this place offers the most authentic Szechuan food! There are several authentic Szechuan food in Chinatown, so when I first saw this place in the downtown, I was doubt about its food, but the fact is completely out of my expectation! I live somewhere nearby, so spicy garden is kind of becoming my kitchen!
author: Chanjuan Z.

description:
Spicy Queen has an affiliation with Potsticker (chinatown), Spicy Empire (san mateo).
saw van parked in front with eateries' name printed on it.

Spicy Queen has dim lighting thruout. (probably not to create a romantic ambience but to save $$.  didn't ventured inside. just ordered to go. .

eats: lunch special cumin lamb w/onions (8.95)
-pricing on menu confusing, thought rice was extra $, wasn't.
 lamb is extra, beef   1$ cheaper, no problem, not a rice eater.
-confirmed i wanted spicy with cumin, didn't expect chilis
-some white onions with thinly sliced lamb, tasty
more lamb than CHI in milpitas
3.5 stars.

take outs:
-lunch menu has lots of noodle offering
spotted lamb, a better value.
-would be 4 stars wouldn't the chili
-service not a problem, serviced quickly......
author: Victor G.

description: real taste of Chinese food and of the good one～ I have recommended it to every Chinese collegues here who miss the cuisine a lot. You can also find Chongqing noodles there.
author: Tianlu W.

description:
The food is quite good, especially for Szechuan style hot pot. 
Why the low rating? BULL$HIT service.

For a place with hot pot, you would think that they would know it would require more attention. People will need UTENSILS, DRINKS, refills on broth when it gets too low in the pot, refills on their tea, MORE FOOD WHEN WE RUN OUT. It was such a burden to get water. It took over an hour and several requests. Whenever I did ask for something, the one waitress made it seem like I was bothering her and caused her suuuuuch annoyance.

And yea, we came with a group. When it came time to pay the bill, we were calculating the best way to split it. They only allow the bill to be split between 2 cards. Fine with us, we didn't have an issue with that policy.  BUUUUUT the female waitress muttered in Mandarin that we were troublesome. YEA I HEARD YOU, FREAKING BIAO ZI! They didn't include automatic gratuity even though were were a group larger than 6. Spicy Queen probably should because with their terrible attitude and service, nobody in their right minds would tip them. My friends and I aren't total a$$holes though and did leave a tip..

but here's another tip: stop being a biao zi and do your fcking job, sha bi!
author: Susy C.

description: We ordered two types of broths, the spicy and numbing broth and the tomato one. Although the spicy and numbing one has a lot of dried red chilies, it wasn't that spicy. The tomato broth was especially sweet and savoury. You can pick the meats and vegetables that you want and they charge you per item. The lamb did not have a strong lamb taste. The potatoes were really starchy and soft when you cook it long enough. There is a good variety of vegetables and all of which we ordered were fresh.
author: James S.

description:
Very delicious authentic Chinese food from the mideast region! Price is moderate and they really serve a decent amount of food! One catch, you need to pay a little extra for the takeaway box and plastic bag which is 10 to 25 cents. 
Highly recommended for those who want to experience real Chinese food!
author: Zoe M.

description: Had to give 4 star for the quality of meat... We got the marinated beef and it was chewy and fatty. Besides that everything was awesome tho. The broths here r very flavorful and the noodles and vegetable very good! Even though it is not all you can eat it was more than plenty! Great service as well.
author: Liz D.

description:
I came here with a friend and it was one of the best authentic Szechuan food I've had in town. I ordered beans and meat sauce noodle. I once had it in Chongqing, and this place made even better taste of it. 
Some restaurant mistakenly think Szechuan food is only about spicy. But it's not. The real Szechuan cuisine has rich aftertaste - after the mouth numbing spicy, you should taste some sweetness, as well as the delicate flavor of the ingredient itself. That's the fascination of Szechuan food - the complex taste burst in your mouth. Unfortunately, only a few restaurant in the Bay Area could do that. 
Spicy Queen exceed the standard and does very good job on balancing the flavor. The noodle I ordered is not too spicy. The beans and the pork are perfect match. I will definitely order it again.
author: F. Z.

description: the good old days of spicy queen has faded away, the food no longer delicious like it used to.  The service was so slow that we had to self serve ourselves, there was only one servant servicing at that time ... not to blame the servant, but the restaurant is obvioualy out of hands, they should reconsider bringing in more arms.  i am giving this restaurant 2 stars because this was once my favourite place to be.
author: Y J.

description: Used to be the best Sichuan restaurant in SF, but only last for the first week since it opened. The quality of the food there is getting worse every time I visited. At last I got totally disappointed of it and leave it forever.
author: Louie Z.

description:
Ok, I am not in to giving bad yelp reviews but this place was sooo bad, I feel compelled to say something. 

We ordered 2 noodle dishes that came in bowls. One was with beef the other only peas & noodle. Both were essentially bowls of hot chili oil with water with some noodles thrown in. It was so greasy and disgusting we could not finish either. The meat was all fat. The peas were dried chick peas. There was about 2 small pieces of bok Choy in each bowl. 

The service was terrible too. The waitress did not know anything about the menu. I asked if I could have tofu added and she said they didn't have any.  She did not know what vegetables were in the vegetable stir fry. She never came to our table without calling her over. 

I would say this place serves the worst food I have ever eaten. 

Don't go there.
author: Jayel L.

description:
We came here about two weeks ago. Had a nice time. Food was ok. We came back and I have to say it was one of the worst meals I have ever had. 
Everything tasted old. Even the fried rice was awful. We brought a friend who had just landed from China. The waiter treated her very bad. Will not visit this restaurant again
author: William S.

description: This was some delicious, unpretentious Chinese food! We got the Szechuan meal for two and we were in and out in 40 minutes for no more than $40!  Can't beat that. The meal hit the spot and everything was delicious. Meal for two included hot and sour soup, Kung Pao chicken, green onion pancake, dry sauteed green beans and steamed rice. Very pleased with this place especially since we just spotted it from the street and decided to try it out.
author: Rebekah C.

description: Terrible! Bad service, tasteless and even bitter soup base. Took the waiter 30 minutes to take the order. When the hotpot finally arrived, he forgot to turn on the burner. So it took an hour and half to eat lunch. Cost more than $30 per person. Ridiculous!
author: Cindy W.

description:
Walking along Geary one evening, we decided to give Spicy Queen a try because after noticing the 'explosive Chilli Chicken' poster on the restaurant window. I go to Z & Y restaurant    frequently and love this dish. 

Everything was super oily. The oil was dripping from the chicken, the black bean sauteed beef, vegetable. The food didn't taste good at all and eating it is like giving an open invitation to acidity.

The waitress was nice and the service was prompt. The prices were reasonable but comparable to Z & Y that has much, much better food and quality.
author: Umer M.

description: Authentic ChongQing cooking, loved the spicy hot pot that they offer. Great taste and reasonable price for the food, good atmosphere. Every dish for the hot pot was good except the pork blood, not juicy at all, (it is pretty hard to find fresh juicy pork blood anyway) I will just avoid it and get something else next time. Parking was kind of hard but I just had to walk a couple of blocks, so worth it for the food. This restaurant would be on my list whenever I visit San Francisco!
author: Jane L.

description: I am not familiar with true Chinese cuisine, I have only eaten at restaurants like Panda Express and PF Changs, and other smaller restaurants. That being said, this was the best Chinese food I've ever had. Though I may not know true Chinese food, I am a foodie and know good quality and preparation when I come across it, and I found it here. We did the pre-set gourmet menu for 3 and it was amazing. Very simple dishes that any American would recognize, but the quality was impeccable. I'm looking forward to visiting SF again soon to try out more of the menu, the stuff that I am less familiar with and which is probably more traditional Chinese. It would be 5-star rating if not for the service, but when food is that good, I'm ok waiting for it.
author: Bryan V.

description: My girlfriend is from Beijing China, and lives in Davis, CA. She visits this place whenever had a chance to stop by the city and loves this restaurant. I believe that says a lot about this restaurant's cuisine!
author: Johnny Y.

description: Authentic good hot pot! Don't know why there are so few customers there. I always go there when I crave for Chinese spicy soupy food.
author: Lin H.

description: Came with my sister and brother in laws who lived in Beijing for 3 years. Legit hot pot. Everything was great.
author: Katie O.

description:
I'm originally from Chongqing. This is the best Chongqing food I could possibly find in the bay area. Chongqing noodle is a must try. If you like spicy and numbing pepper, please ask for extra spicy and numbing. It is very delicious. Nowhere else I can find this in the bay area. Little Sichuan is not even close to this good. I can tell the seasonings are imported from Chongqing. It's so authentic and good.

Like the other Yelpers claimed, the service at this place is horrible. However, I do not expect good services going to Chinese restaurants. The food is worth 5 stars by itself. And 5 stars to the chef too!

I live in the east bay (Dublin, CA). So it's a hike for me to get there, but it's worth it!
author: erik b.

description:
I can not tell the different from 3 dishes we ordered. They all had the same flavor/taste. They're good spicy tho but too much oil. If i decided to go back again I would get only 1 dish and ask for less oil and try other dishes.

1 star down for service. I don't need that much attentive service but I did ask for hot tea and a drink which I had to wait for too long and also longer when I ask for more water.
author: Kei S.

description:
HOLY NUMBING PEPPERS BATMAN! This place is the bomb. 

Im a fan of hot pot and I like my food spicy! This place delivers on both. The food is 5 stars- every dish was bursting with flavor and my taste buds were in heaven. 

The grilled squid was a pleasant surprise (the hint of cumin made it oh so amazing) 

My husband and I had the custom hot pot with a double broth option and it was just sooooooooo GOOD! 

I will be back for sure. 

The only reason for the 4 star rating is because the service was def lacking. Our waiters although super nice- never checked in nor did they bring us basic supplies. we had to ask for bowls for our hot pot, spoons, and ladles for the soup. 

But it wasnt a deal breaker- im laid back and it didnt stop me from enjoying this delicious food.
author: Ashley H.

description:
I had a great time at Spicy Queen tonight. Growing up in a first generation Chinese-American home, with highly fatigued, over worked immigrant parents from Hong Kong, trying to keep their heads above water, managing language barriers, balancing being acclimated, yet Chinese; my mother couldn't always explain everything verbally to an Americanized son. But one thing she wanted me to fully comprehend in my vernacular was artful cooking through demonstration. Good Chinese cooking through balanced umami flavors, skilled cutting, quality ingredients, vibrant array of textures, attentive cooking and surprise elements of freshness. 

Often at various Chinese restaurants within SF, I know they are missing the mark--overburdened kitchen staffs, fast turnover demands, mediocre ingredient sourcing, overuse of cornstarch--leading to passable, but ordinary flavors, and sloppy presentation. 

Spicy Queen is none of those things. My guest and I ordered modest dishes--scallion pancakes, spicy oil cold tripe, and a lamb hot pot. But each dish was remarkable. The scallion pancakes were thin, crisp, served hot, that you'd only receive from a highly skilled cook with good practice of temperature, oil, and kneading. The spicy oil cold tripe was tender, artfully cut in easy to eat bites, generous in seasoning with a surprise of sweet vinegar, sesame seeds, crisp, fresh soy sprouts, and refreshing cilantro. The hot pot, oh the hot pot, generous, flavorful slow cooked broth, authentic, unique vegetables combinations, high quality lamb with just the right tender layer of  skin, rustic, and real. 

Now for novice Sichuan eaters, just know the primary feeling in the dishes is heat, but within that numbing heat, are nuances--tang, sweetness, savory, nutty. Spicy Queen satisfied all of it. 

Each dish arrived in careful sequence, severed at the right temperatures, portions were generous without being overwhelming, served in elegant organic form ceramics and steel pots akin to the practices of the best eateries in Mainland China. The interior is compact, but comfortable, and again, possesed an adroit flow. It was artful--all of it--the kind that affirmed what my mom tried to teach me through many years of patient teachings. Attention to detail, the high level of quality, was all given at kind, reasonable price points. I felt the same kind of love you receive from your most cherished family cooked meals. The quality was 100%. 

Thank you for a great time! This restaurant is a gem. The staff is caring, elegant, and understated. I hope that things stay the same here, because I hope to keep a great relationship with this restaurant to cherish. I know my mom would definitely be a supporter of this excellence.
author: N T.

description: I like the noodles better than the hot pot
author: Patrick K.

description: 巴适得很! After living in Sichuan for 8 years and eating Sichuan food every single day, I can say without reservation that the food here is amazing. There was only one person staffed when we came so she was crazy busy but the wait was well worth it and I'm sure it's not the norm. Great food!
author: Dustin M.

description: The service sucks there. Basically there is only one waitress and can poorly perform the service. Nobody waits in line and the sign up sheet doesn't work at all. 5 people come without any reservation just because they have 5 ppl.
author: Bill L.

description: Came here randomly because a restaurant up the street was closed and I'm so glad we found this place. I've been here a couple of times now and I love it. I always order the vermicelli with minced pork-- it's amazing. I've also had the explosive chicken, eggplant, duck chin, fish and tofu pot, and tan tan noodle. I've never been disappointed.
author: Nicole H.

description: This is very sichuan food... I will let my friends know. Traditional. Cucumber, huiguorou, spicy pork, all good. They even have chongqing xiaomian and many small dishes. Hope.you can check it out when you come to SF.
author: Quan Y.

description:
Was amused by the name and came here for dinner with friends.

We didn't have the Shabu but tried quite a few of their Szechuan dishes. The combination pot, Dan Dan noodles, lamb skewers and beef with bamboo shoots were all excellent and well seasoned. 

I really appreciated how the dishes weren't just spicy for the sake of showing off how spicy it could be but balanced with herbs and seasoning. Also tried the seasonal vegetables - pea shoots with garlic which were very fresh. Probably not the best place for Beijing specialties but the beef roll pancake was nice and thin and had unexpected peanut sauce in the roll.

Service was more than sufficient. Had to ask for water a few times but otherwise service was very good by Chinese restaurant standards.

Will definitely recommend and return.
author: Tina G.

description: Good spot!  Came I and it was super busy. We had to put our name down on a clipboard and wait for someone to call us. Had no idea how long the wait would be but we decided to wait anyway. As we were about to leave, a waitress came over to give us a seat. Let me tell you, so glad we waited.  Very different dishes and the food was fresh!  I ordered the sweet n sour shrimp and it was beyond good .  The sake was also great
author: Yisel F.

description: The noodle is not bad. But DO NOT ORDER HOT POT!!! It tastes like they put a whole can of salt and msg inside. The most salty hot pot I've ever had in my life!!! They didn't feel sorry for that and just add some hot water to the soup. That's it.
author: Max Y.

description: Cold weather,having a hot pot here.they just opened a month ago.spicy hot pot taste is very good.price is not high,we really enjoy and will come back soon
author: Cindy T.

description: This is a place for people who like spicy and Szechuan style chinese foods. I will not recommend to anyone who are not use to the oilly Szechan spicy foods. I personally is in love with this place and so as my boy friend, we both love spicy foods, specially Szechan foods.
author: Jasmine Y.

description:
14.12.24.       1st drop in
                        Rare walkout with no service

0 Star ... check my record ... might be the
                1 star I ever posted in 6+ years.
                NOT bad service ... 
                Just plain IGNORED 
                11 stared at and ... 
                     I am not going to swear ...                 

I don't waste time posting anything under
    3 stars ... waste of time and unproductive.

This was posted to wise up the owner and
   Warn others for now. 
   And it was ... u be the JUDGE

   Walked in and during 6 mins
   2 waitresses looks torward me
       And I am "Casper" invisible ghost
       I walked further in 
       Sometimes I raised my hand
   2 behind counter working the 
             Machine ... Walked torward me
                Staring and went back working
                 the orange juicing machine
                 Like ... 
                    not my job it's the waitress'
    
Never in my life ... no exaggeration 
  
  4 staff & 
  11 ... 2+ secs looking at me

Seen this a past workplace ... either:
   I don't see ... passing the buck
   Zoned out ... tired or concetrating
   Simple underpaid rude staff
   
11 times passed over ...
  Too many flukes

Will not visit until I see positive reviews
Meaning they wised up

Given ... 
    New business
    Stressed
    Overwork
    Green
    Newbie
    They were not slacking off 


Maybe next time ... not soon
author: S.K. Y.

description: Worst service ever. Took 30 minutes of waving the servers down to just to get them to take our order. Then food came out 20 minutes later. It shouldn't take 20 minutes to throw "broth" in a bowl and bring it out. We had the spicy chicken broth and the whole thing was just chili oil, no broth.  The whole experience was just bad. It even took 2 waiters and 10 minutes to get our bill. Never coming again
author: Ryan L.

description: Had the most delicious meal tonight! We didn't try the hot pot, but had a la carte - broccoli beef, salt and pepper shrimp, green onion cake, house chow mein, sautéed pea shoots with garlic, lamb skewers. Everything was fantastic! Not greasy or salty. Warning - the large rice is really large!
author: Rebecca C.

description: My all time favorite authentic Chinese/Szechuan restaurant in the city! Recommend the roast fish, Chongqing Noodle, hot pot, spicy cold chicken, etc! Anything looks so yummy I gotta try more!
author: Susie W.

description: This is a very authentic Chong Qing restaurant,  they have very good szechwan dishes! Highly recommend the "Noodle with peas and meat sauces"!
author: Jessica Z.

description: Finally some authentic Sichuan food in San Francisco. Sooo much better than Chili House or Z&Y. I needed a Sichuan fix, and this place is perfect. Don't miss it. Hard to find a place worth your money, but this place is it. Enjoy!
author: Craig P.

description: Brought a small group of friends here for the all you can eat hotpot. Got the 1/2 & 1/2 spicy and mild pot. Ordered up plenty of meats and veggies along with rounds of Tsingtao beer. Overall the food was pretty good, the service was rather slow as it seemed there was only one waitress for the entire restaurant on a Tuesday night.
author: Shane B.

description: Omg, this restaurant is so arrogant. We were in line for a while and finally got a table. I had sore throat so ordered some noodle and asked for non spicy option for one of them. And half hour later, our dishes finally arrived. Not only the wonton tasted not fresh at all but also the waiter brought my noodles covered in spicy sauces. The waiter refused to change my noodle to non spicy one and insisted that I didn't specify the non spicy option when ordering. He refused to order more food for us as well. It is ridiculous! Worse food and service ever!
author: Linda S.

description: They used a lot of starch in their sauces, too much breading on deep fried meats. The quality of the meats such as chicken and beef is not high. The beef taste mediocre and the chicken taste pretty horrible, It's the spiciness of the dishes that make its OK to eat. I probably won't be coming back.
author: Robert S.

description: The worst restaurant I've gone. Only two servant. So bad service! And ask for at least 18% tips! Not worth it!
author: Jiajun P.

description: The traditional Szechuan cuisine. The noodles taste so good that we are full just before the hot pot is coming. Also the hot pot is great too.
author: Claire C.

description: Minus 1 star for the 50 minute wait time. But everything was delicious and so worth the wait. They only had 1 waiter working during the lunch hours, which I felt wasn't fair for him. He was running around all over the place, and the place was nearly full. I hope they hire an additional waiter for lunch, to make the service run smoother.
author: J P.

description:
Great food.  Service not an issue as others as noted.  Came on one of the coldest nights in San Francisco. Obviously they heat the food but not the restaurant too well. 

Plan to come back in the warmer weather to enjoy the food again.
author: Ed John ..

description:
probably the best szechuan spicy chili oil soup base for hot pot i've found in the bay area thus far.

ingredients are of questionable quality, service is slow cause there's one poor high school kid who handles the entire restaurant, but when you crave a mouthful of chili oil, spicy queen hits the spot.
author: Sherman L.

description: We already signed the seat for 2 and waiting for half an hour, and then the party of 5 comes, they didn't sign or reserve but take the seats intermediately. The waitress totally ignore us and be so mean. There are also some other groups of people signed before the party of 5.
author: Mary Meiyin W.

description: Kinda meh. On the upside, i actually found the service quite fine, unlike most people here. The fish tofu was excellent and the meat was fine. The herbal broth was fine. but the spicy broth was DISGUSTING. not any sort of actual broth, just all oil. i like to actually eat/drink the broth, and there was no way that was happening here - like drinking a bottle of veg oil. yuck.
author: Erica W.

description: I'm giving it two stars because the aesthetic and ambiance. However, the food was just not my style. It left a very weird feeling in my mouth and the sauce was too greasy.
author: Raakin H.

description: Normally, I'm not involved in writing reviews at all but I don't know why their ratings are low. I like Szechuan food and I have to say the foods are very good and very reasonable price. Service is not bad at all. I will definitely come back.
author: Sathit N.

description: Very decent hotpot, very authentic Chongqing style. Fairly clean and decently priced.
author: Eric L.

description: Zhuoping said food was great. Very nice China feel decor. Spacious dining area. Bathroom was clean. Friendly service. Bang bang de.
author: Xx Z.

description:
Good service and tasty spicy food here, it's kind of real Szechuan food.
Haha, coz I am a Szechuan people...
author: Cici T.

description: I came here for my birthday with a lot of family members (18 to be exact) The staff there were friendly and welcoming to the many people that i had in my party. I brought a cake and there was no additional charge which was very nice of them and they also provided new plates and forks for the cake (which they didn't have to do). The food tasted really good and came out fairly quickly. I will be coming back here again and this time to try hot pot. The only reason i didn't give 5 stars was because of the way the food came out we got the chicken out first but not the rice with it, by the time the rice came out the chicken started getting cold. The other thing is the service wasn't quick but the guy who was working was really nice and always had a smile.
author: Nelly L.

description: Best spicy foods in Chinatown.I like Spicy chicken  Noodle pees and Hot pot.The taste of spicy chicken as same as my hometown.
author: Scarlett Z.

description: Nice place, they provide really original Sichuan style hotpot pot soup base, service is ok and needs to be improved.
author: Feng H.

description:
After reading those negative reviews, we tried this place out for their lunch specials.

Food was authentic and tongue numbing for sure.  Scallion pancakes were okay, but the amount doesn't justify its price.

Based on the quality of their lunch specials, we'll be back to try hot pot among others.
author: daphne w.

description: Finally try some new hot pot place..  I noticed they have remodeled But I think still they same owner. Anyway...  some of foods were ok. But they need to wash there veggies. And there plates.. so dirty. And there service is suck..  I tired like I own them money. .OMG...  Never come back ...
author: sean c.

description: I selfishly hope this place doesn't get incredibly popular because I've never had to wait for a table for very long when I've gone - but, if they do, they deserve it.  Their noodles are made in-house and are absolutely delicious!  I've enjoyed all the dishes I've ordered - the only one that fell short was the chongqing chicken; it's good, but I've had better elsewhere.  Their noodles with peas and meat sauce was incredible!  The place is clean, decor is nice, and the service is prompt and polite.  I haven't had the hotpot yet, but it looks promising!
author: Lyn Y.

description: Very good szechuan restaurant with excellent chonq qing la chi chi (explosive chicken).  Enjoy the bamboo walls, and water fountain as well.  Service could be improved, but a good value all things considered.  My new favorite szechuan restaurant these days.
author: Z Z.

description: One of my favorite Sichuan food in the town! Like their noodles, pots, dishes and the fish! I'll definitely recommend their noodles and boiled fish!
author: Xi L.

description: Holly molly spicy and super yummy!!! My to go spot :) just perpare need to wait little when lunch time coz only 1 server.
author: DH L.

description: I brought my parents here for their first hot pot experience. It was fantastic, and everyone loved it! Very flavorful spicy broth that had a kick but was not painful, high quality ingredients like pork belly and prawns, and a cheerful waiter whose limited English did not get in the way of helping us navigate the experience.
author: Lisa O.

description:
Three of us went to Spicy Queen for lunch.  I expected a hot pot as I ordered a combination of food for hot pot.  I mentioned that they may keep it on the milder side.  Rather than a hot pot to cook, the chefs had cooked everything and the food was sitting in a pool of oil and red peppers. This was not from the lunch menu but from the hot pot selection.  More like $$$.
Since it was lunch, I didn't know whether this was the norm.  All the ingredients were soggy and oily.  It was only mid-meal did I see other customers with hot pot style.  By then, it was too late to return.  
Hot pot, maybe yes...but didn't get to cook.  Pre cooked....no way.
author: bernie s.

description: I love the noodles they made! The noodle with peas and meat sauce is my favorite!!! very tasty!!!!And i also tried some dishes right there, i think it tasted much better than the Grand hot pot which is near by this Chinese cuisine. The food are not too spicy, and u can order more or less spicy if u like it. They have lunch special on Mon to Fri. And i saw they also do the hot pot, and i smelt that was awesome! i did not do it yet, i just smelt it, but i will do! Cuz that was smelt so good. By the way, the waiter was very kind to me. anyway, this is a good place to have a meal.
author: Andy Z.

description: Service is horrible and the food was mediocre, if you don't speak the language hard to communicate. Did not understand the difference b/w read and white meat
author: Madhvesh B.

description: It's organized Sichuan food.I love the shredded pork with garlic sauce and noddles,there's nice equipment and services.
author: Yunjing H.

description: Most authentic Sichuan restaurant in SF right now. It would be nice, though, if the waitress could smile at customers once in a while, instead of just giving her usual angry glare.
author: Ritch G.

description: Good flavoring, numbing spicy fish/beef is quite good, but needs bigger portion for the amount they're charging. Parking can be a problem and if you don't mind dodging those bums and drug addicts.
author: Simon C.

description: This is one of my favorite Sichuan restaurants. The chef prepares authentic dishes with fresh ingredients. The presentation of the dishes are top notch. They also have karaoke rooms upstairs, and the staff is very friendly. Highly recommend this place !!
author: Liana Z.

description: Service is prefect.the decoration is really authentic! The most important thing is the food is awesome.
author: Boya Z.

description: The best Sichuan in San Francisco...  good tan tan noodle.  Chungching latsuzzi...   have been here twice and will come here more often.   ................. Authentic flavor and good malla,  tung nubming flavor
author: Sam A.

description: It's a very original Sichuan restaurant. The food here is very tasty. And the service is also good.
author: Brigitte W.
